description: Simply by people transporting flyers describing the symptoms, to having outside help come and speak to people in healthy areas on what to expect, can be a crticial point in supporting the effort in stopping the spread of Ebola. I think it will work because people today want to help eachother, and themselves, and by keeping the infection away, people all have a common goal to unite and fight for. A part in this idea that i'm a little shakey about is what to do when they become isolated, because we can't transport healthy people in and get them infected too. Though we will be able to isolate the infected, it will be a bigger feat to cure the disease, but some ideas have been thrown aorund. The article "WHO ponders treating Ebola-infected people with blood of survivors" is an informative article that puts plainly what we have in our fight for Ebola so far.
summary: Though there is only 2 patients with Ebola in the United Stated at the moment, there are still thousands of infected people in Africa that haven't been treated, or in some cases know they have Ebola. That's why we should put into effect a plan, to help the masses out while researchers try to find a solution to the problem of Ebola. This plan would be Identification, Communication, Neutralization. First people need to be able to identify the symptoms for the disease. Then communicating that there are X amount of people in this village can help identify where it's spreading. And then neutralizing and isolating the infected areas from healthy areas will help stop the spread. The participation from the public is key in slowing down Ebola.
title: Identification, Communication, Neutralization
